title: Heads and tales, or, Anecdotes and stories of quadrupeds and other beasts chiefly connected with incidents in the histories of more or less distinguished men /
snippet: Captain Ommaney,* who Jed one of the travelling parties in 1851 sent out from the ships under Austin in search of Franklin on the 12th of June, the day before he arrived at the ships, met with a laughable accident, although it might have had a serious termination.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: towards St. Mary's Wynd and the straggling street which ascended from thence to the convent of St. Mary de Placentia (whence to this day it is still named the Pleasance), were well armed with habergeons and caps of steel, swords, daggers, knives, and Jed wood axes — for the paths of life, even for the greatest and noblest in Scotland, were not strewn with roses in those days, but rather with briars in the shape of blades and spears, woes, wai^s, tumults, and turmoils, such as their descendants  cannot realize in these our days of peace and good order.

title: My first visit to Europe:
author: Dickinson, Andrew
snippet: Where Tweed and Teviot in soft confluence glide, Memory shall slit o'er the romantic dale, 'Mid Jed and Dryburgh's groves on the hillside, And Ednam's lonely song-enchanted vale.

title: My first visit to Europe:
author: Dickinson, Andrew
snippet: On the banks of the Jed are many caves dug out of rocks, supposed to be hiding-places in the old wars.

title: My first visit to Europe:
author: Dickinson, Andrew
snippet: The south aisle of Jedburgh  Abbey was once occupied as a grammar school, where Thomson the poet received the rudiments of his education, after his father removed from Ednam to Southdean on the Jed.

title: My first visit to Europe:
author: Dickinson, Andrew
snippet: "Pure parent stream, Whose pastoral banks first heard my Doric reed ; And sylvan Jed, thy tributary brook!"

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: — Jed, pure be thy crystal streams, and hallowed thy sylvan banks ! Sweet Isabella Lindsay, may peace dwell in thy bosom, uninterrupted, except by the tumultuous throbbings of rapturous love ! That love-kindling eye must beam on another, not on me ; that graceful form must bless another' s arms ; not mine !

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Return to Jedburgh — walk up Jed with some ladies to be shown Love-lane and Blackburn, two fairy scenes.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: All the towns here have the appearance of old, rude grandeur, but the people extremely idle— Jed a fine romantic little river.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Turnip and sheep husbandry,  their great improvements — Mr. M'- Dowal, at Caverton Mill, a friend of Mr. Ainslie' s, with whom I dined to-day, sold his sheep, ewe and lamb together, at two guineas a piece — wash their sheep before shearing — seven or eight pounds of washen wool in a fleece — low markets, consequently low rents — fine lands not above sixteen shillings a Scotch acre — magnificence  of farmers and farm-houses — come up Teviot and up Jed to Jedburgh to lie, and so wish myself a good night.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns: containing his poems, songs, and correspondence.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: And Eden scenes on crystal Jed, ^ And Ettrick banks now roaring red,

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.

snippet: On returning, therefore, to his housein Badenoch, he had called his men together, and Jed three hundred MacPhersonsto join the Chevalier's standard at Edinburgh.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Of thislatter kind of caves, there are many in Scotland, asupon the banks of the Teviot, the Jed, and otherrivers ; but they are much more rude, and muchless complicated, than those of Hawthornden.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Many moss-troopers are said to havebeen drowned in a deep eddy of the Jed near Jedburgh.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: These were maintained at HumeCastle, at the Tower of Edgerhope, or Edgerstane,near the source of the Jed, upon the ridge of theSoltra Hills, at Dunbar, Dunpender (or TrapraineJLaw, North Berwick Law, and other eminences;and their light was a signal for the Scottish forcesto assemble at Edinburgh and Haddington, abandoning to waste and pillage all the southern counties.2 Till the very last occasion of hostility betweenEngland and Scotland, this mode of defensive warwas resorted to in the latter kingdom.
